content: Naruto tailed beasts and their jinchuriki

Here’s a concise overview of the **Tailed Beasts (Bijū)** and their known **Jinchūriki** in the *Naruto* series:



| Tailed Beast | Tails | Name          | Jinchūriki (Known)                                                                 |
|--------------|-------|---------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Shukaku      | 1     | One-Tail      | Gaara (Suna), Bunpuku (Iwa), Yugito Nii (Kumo, filler)                             |
| Matatabi     | 2     | Two-Tails     | Yugito Nii (Kumo)                                                                 |
| Isobu        | 3     | Three-Tails   | Yagura (Kiri), Rin Nohara (Konoha, temporarily)                                   |
| Son Gokū     | 4     | Four-Tails    | Rōshi (Iwa)                                                                      |
| Kokuō        | 5     | Five-Tails    | Han (Iwa)                                                                         |
| Saiken       | 6     | Six-Tails     | Utakata (Kiri)                                                                   |
| Chōmei       | 7     | Seven-Tails   | Fū (Taki)                                                                         |
| Gyūki        | 8     | Eight-Tails   | Killer B (Kumo), Blue B (Kumo, temporarily)                                      |
| Kurama       | 9     | Nine-Tails    | Naruto Uzumaki (Konoha), Kushina Uzumaki (Konoha), Minato Namikaze (Konoha, briefly) |
| Ten-Tails    | 10    | Jūbi          | Hagoromo Ōtsutsuki (briefly), Obito Uchiha (temporarily), Madara Uchiha (briefly) |

### Key Notes:
- **Jinchūriki** are humans who have a tailed beast sealed inside them.
- Some jinchūriki (like Yugito Nii) appear only in filler arcs or non-canon material.
- The **Ten-Tails** is a special case, as it is the combination of all nine tailed beasts and was never permanently sealed into a single jinchūriki.

Would you like details on a specific tailed beast or jinchūriki?
